<h2>Distinguishing Features</h2>

On account of its large size (leafy shoots can be &gt;5 mm wide and longer than 5 cm), prominent teeth on large, deep green leaves bearing a conspicuous basal pleat, the common Plagiochila porelloides is perhaps the most moss-like of our regional liverworts, growing as it often does in relatively large clumps. Close inspection should show a stem devoid of underleaves and hairs, with large unlobed and asymmetrical lateral leaves alternating along the stem, their bases of attachment running down along the length of the stem (&quot;decurrent, see photo). The leaves are often wide-spreading and the teeth are quite variable in number and size.

<h2>Habitat</h2>

Moist to mesic humus, rock outcrops, boulders, cliffs, cutbanks, decayed wood, tree bases, and streambanks in the lowland and montane zones
